children.title: Create linked component
children.ingress: Define your own components that have linked properties to the backend

children.code: const CodeViewer = ({ code, codeLang }) => (<SyntaxHighlighter language={codeLang} style={dark}>{code}</SyntaxHighlighter>);

children.value: Then connect the component to the backend

children.code: const CodeView = createLinkWrapper(CodeViewer, ({ code, codeLang }) => ({ code, codeLang }));

children.value:
The connecting function in the createLinkWrapper function will map the properties from the backend and listen to changes in the properties, and also be editable in on the page.

You can then connect the component with an id in another component by just giving it an id property.
All connected nodes can have children and then you don't need to define an id, the children will be linked if they are mapped by the application

children.code:
componentRegistry.setComponents( { "row": LinkedRow, "col": LinkedCol, "code": CodeView, "docs": Docs, "quickstart": QuickStart, "faq": Faq, "nodeproduct": Product, "index": Index, "about": Example, "page": Example, "text": LinkedText, "image": LinkedImage, "template": () => (

custom

) });

children.title: Change to the App component
children.ingress: Link the react page to the backend

children.title: Define custom nodes
children.ingress: Create your own nodes in C#

children.value: They will automatically appear in the editor and you can map them to a react component.

children.title: LinkedComponent
children.ingress: Extend the LinkedComponent if you want to change more in how the link is used
